race.name: CIRREM
race.tagline: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel in rural Roubaix.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat, wind, and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling northern Illinois farmland. Moderate elevation with farmland scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Illinois event. Rolling farmland terrain with rural location and limited organization.

biased_opinion.summary: CIRREM is a regional event in rural Roubaix, northern Illinois. The rolling farmland terrain offers moderate climbing with farmland scenery, but the rural location, limited amenities, and moderate organization keep it firmly in Tier 3. Roubaix is a small town with limited lodging and dining. It's a solid regional event for Illinois cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Illinois gravel race with rolling farmland terrain. Worth it for Illinois cyclists seeking a local event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Rural rolling Illinois farmland gravel in Roubaix.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Illinois and want a local rolling gravel eventâ€”yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of stateâ€”there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Midwest events: Gravel Worlds, Almanzo 100, Dirty Kanza. For similar regional events: other Illinois gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Roubaix has very limited lodging. Princeton or Peru have more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel with moderate climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel in rural Roubaix.

non_negotiables.why: Rolling Illinois terrain requires sustained effort.
Illinois spring/fall means heat and wind are possible.
Rural location requires self-sufficiency and preparation.

topics.heat: Racing in Illinois heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel in rural Roubaix.

logistics.explanation: Registration opens 9pm November 27th and "will fill up in a few minutes" for 500 spots maximum. Race day runs breakfast at 8AM, check-in until 9:45AM, 10AM start at Cumming Tap. The self-supported format means minimal race infrastructure beyond the halfway checkpoint with food and drink.

length.explanation: The 100k distance produces finish times from Dillon McNeill's 3:06:38 record down to 6+ hour survivors. Recent Masters winner Ross Eoriatti finished in 4:14:50 with tight gaps behind him. In 2025's thawing gravel conditions, that translates to plenty of suffering without excessive dark-hours grinding. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Post-race scene puts it: "Please stay around afterwards and have a good time at the Tap as long as you like. The Tap is pretty awesome, and it's in Cumming, for crying out loud."

technicality.explanation: Madison County's winding hills include bridges with "spaces between the boards that eat wheels for lunchâ€”seriously, a friend separated his shoulder last weekend on it." The 5000+ feet of climbing comes via grinding rollers rather than technical descents, though conditions create handling challenges when gravel turns to "peanut-buttery build up." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Over 5000 feet of climbing across 63 miles through Madison County's rolling terrain. The race organizers describe it as "winding hills" that test persistence rather than explosive power. It's Iowa elevationâ€”death by a thousand papercuts rather than mountain passes. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 42Â°F and lows of 24Â°F, with a 41% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 26 mph. Late February timing delivers everything from 2019's "foggy with periods of rain turning to snow late, low 30's" to 2022's "4 inches of snow two days prior." Race organizer remembers "stopping several times to wring the water out of my mittens" and riders with "bright-red gloveless hands." It's winter warfare, not marketing copy. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Cumming, Iowa sits at corn-growing elevationâ€”essentially sea level for racing purposes. The thin air you'll experience comes from 30-degree temperatures hitting your lungs, not altitude. Any breathing difficulty stems from frozen February conditions, not oxygen deprivation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds â€” no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Frozen gravel through Madison County in February conditions offers adventure, but it's more 'survive the elements' than 'explore the unknown.' The self-supported format and open roads add real riskâ€”organizers explicitly warn about slippery conditions and high speeds with car traffic. It's adventure through attrition rather than exotic terrain.

prestige.explanation: Sixteen years deep, CIRREM bills itself as "the OG of winter gravel races" with enough reputation to sell out in minutes. Dave Mable's singlespeed race report earned coverage in CX Magazine. But this remains Iowa grassroots racing where winners ride "singlespeed mountain bikes, fender'ed cross bikes" rather than pro pelotons.

race_quality.explanation: This is self-supported racing with open roads and a checkpoint roughly in the middleâ€”bare bones organization that puts the burden on you. Winners finish around 4 hours while others suffer for 6+ hours on frozen gravel through Madison County's winding hills. The pile-up among leaders in slippery conditions shows what happens when winter racing meets minimal course management.

experience.explanation: Starts and finishes at Cumming Tap, which immediately tells you this isn't some sanitized corporate event. Two inches of overnight snow followed by race-day sleet in 20-degree tempsâ€”that's the authentic winter gravel experience most races only pretend to offer. You'll remember every frozen mile of those 64 miles through Madison County.

community.explanation: The equipment listâ€”"mountain bikes, cross bikes, ss's, fenders, fixies, fat bikes and even road bikes"â€”shows this crowd prioritizes showing up over showing off. Post-race hangs at Cumming Tap with awards "a few hours after winners come in, but still before everyone is off course." The organizer's advice: "ride with a buddy if you think you'll be out there a while."

field_depth.explanation: Men's Masters category saw 18% DNF rate in 2025 with tight racingâ€”8-minute gap from first to third. Winners have emerged from singlespeeds and fender'ed cross bikes, indicating more heart than horsepower. Categories include tandem and fat bike divisions, suggesting inclusive rather than elite competitive depth. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Race morning schedule puts it: "8:00AM â€“ Breakfast, 8-9:45AM â€“ Rider check-in, 10:00AM â€“ CIRREM begins, 3:00PM â€“ Awards"

value.explanation: Registration includes 8AM breakfast, halfway checkpoint food, post-race lunch, and finishing at a tap house in Cumming, Iowa. The format strips away unnecessary support to focus spending on the experience itself. No prize purse data available, but you're paying for winter suffering and community, not payouts.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Cumming, Iowa doesn't command destination race pricing for lodging and meals. Nearest major airport likely Des Moines, about 40 miles out, keeping travel costs reasonable. The race's "absolutely no transfers and no refunds" policy and minute-long sellout suggest pricing hits the sweet spot for committed winter racers. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

citations.label: tri2max.com: Gloves Or Pogies What Is Faster For Me On A Gravel Race

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Barry Roubaix Gravel Race - 62mi Wave 1 (2025)
videos.description:
Threading the needle to avoid a massive crash to get to the finish line. Not the race I wanted, but considering the alternative I'll take it.

ðŸ‘‰ Hey! SUBSCRIBE for more race content! ðŸ‘‰ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1

The Barry Roubaix was held on April 12, 2025 in Hastings, MI. I raced the 62 mile version (actually almost 65 miles) which had around 4,800 ft of climbing. Temperature was decent, in the lower 50s with full sun and no wind. I saw the staging coral already starting to fill up 40 minutes before the start so I had to cut my warmup short and get in line around 50th. I tried to move up once the race started but kept getting shuffled back. The 3 sisters felt ok and I was trying to monitor my effort and not burn any unnecessary matches. However, that strategy left me further back in the pack then I wanted.

Just after 4 miles in on a seemingly uneventful section of the course, all hell broke loose. At nearly 30 mph the group started to suddenly slow down. Little did I know there was a crash on the left that would cause a cascade of overreactions and eventual crashes everywhere. Applying my brakes I noticed I wasn't slowing down fast enough. I swerved out of the way of the first few riders attempting to stop then all I saw and heard was crashing all around me. Time slowed down and all I thought was to steer through it rather than attempting to stop. I remember running over something on my left and something hitting my arm/shoulder on my right. The next thing I knew is that I was through the chaos. Crash can be seen in more detail here:   https://youtu.be/DG557fyV0YY?si=i9C2Dw_EolsY95Yk

I somehow made it through the crash unscathed but lost the front group of about 50+ riders. Not ideal but better than being in a nasty crash. A small group of us chased back for 6 miles (15 minutes) until we reached the front group just in time for Shaw road. Well, that was too much and I completely blew up. I struggled for the next hour until I latched onto a group after the Farm around mile 30. After mile 48 our group caught another group of about 20 and we swelled to nearly a 50 rider peloton. This massive group stayed together until the final mile into the finish. I didn't have much in legs at the end but was able to work myself into finishing 7th in the group sprint (though we were all together and got the same time). Somehow I got a Strava crown for 10th best ever sprint in that section which I will be taking as a moral victory, lol.  I ended up 73rd overall which was a PR but shy of my goal of top 50. 

ðŸ‘‰ Hey! SUBSCRIBE for more race content! ðŸ‘‰ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1

videos.title: Barry Roubaix Gravel Race 2025 - 65 Miles
videos.description:
Over 4000 racers made it this year to Hastings, Michigan for one of the biggest gravel races in the world - Barry Roubaix. 
This year we couldn't ask for a better weather (around 50F and plenty of sunshine).
I finished 35th out of 116  in 45-49 age category and 310th out of 1034 overall in the 65 mile race with official time 03:31:39

00:00 - Intro
02:00 - Wave 2 start
06:54 - 3 Sisters
17:39 - Shaw Rd
25:48 - Sager Rd
37:36 - Head Lake Off Road
47:03 - Chainsaw Massacre

videos.title: CIRREM 2012
videos.description: CIRREM.  100k gravel bike race in Cumming, IA.

videos.title: Cirrem 2013
videos.description: 2013 Edition of CIRREM. A 63 mile gravel road race with a little over 5000 ft of climbing. CIRREM occurs every February, where the weather won't keep 150 stoic iowans off their bikes. Starting and ending from the Cummings tap, in Cummings Iowa, start time temps hovered around 18F and it warmed up to balmy 31F with a south westerly wind of 5 to 10 miles per hour.
videos.curation_reason: Only video specifically about CIRREM race with course details including 63 miles, 5000ft climbing, and February weather conditions.

videos.title: Unbound Gravel 200 - Pro Men, Full Race Onboard Footage
videos.description:
53rd Pro Men
326km/200mi Gravel Race

My Patreon: http://patreon.com/justinmcquerry/
Race Info: http://unboundgravel.com/

Bike - Ibis Hakka: http://ibiscycles.com/bikes/hakka-mx
Tools & Tubeless Plugs - Prestacycle: https://prestacycle.com
Frame Bags - MoosePacks: http://moosepacks.com/
Ti Bolts and Axles: http://metireggioemilia.it/
Wheels - BERD: http://berdspokes.com/
Tires - Maxxis: https://www.maxxis.com/us/tires/bicycle/

Unbound, the biggest gravel race of them all. The start list at the 2024 edition of Unbound Gravel was the highest caliber field ever seen at this race, including the current UCI Gravel World Champion, several current UCI World Tour athletes, a majority of the LifeTime Grand Prix Athletes, former Paris-Roubaix winners and a whole lot of properly fast folks.

My goal for this race was to have a clean race, and conserve as much energy in the first 100 miles so that I could stay on the power for the latter half of the race, when other athletes would start to fall apart with the duration and rising temps. The race started insanely fast, more reminiscent of a 100 mile road race than a 9+ hour gravel race. I was very cautious in the first few hours, and unfortunately found myself chasing back on to the lead group several times as riders were flatting, crashing and cracking just a few wheels ahead of me in the first few decisive sections.

The lead group came into Aid Station 1 with ~60 riders, and unfortunately I panicked a bit coming out of the first Aid stop and burnt a match too many - I came off of the lead group here, but sat up for a few minutes to regather myself and get ready for the next 5+ hours of steady chasing. I quickly fell in with a chase group after Aid 1, and we were picking off riders almost immediately. Not long after the notorious Little Egypt, Andrew Dillman and I were able to pick up Truman Glasgow and Konny Looser, and the 4 of us were able to catch a group including Niki Terpstra, Laurens ten Dam, Thomas Dekker, Tobin Ortinblad, Rob Britton and several other fast folks. This new chase group of ~12 riders rotated well and smooth, and we were picking off riders through the latter part of the race that is mostly tame gravel with a few climbs.

Unfortunately, with around 40km of racing left on a descent, the two riders in front of me hit a rock, and was unable to avoid hitting this rock at ~45kph, causing a flat for all three of us. I was able to ride for a short while before I had to inflate the tire again, but I didn't jostle the sealant around and had to stop to inflate the tire two more times. The third time I had to stop, with around 30km of racing left, I was unable to regain contact with this chase group and rode solo until the last 3km.

The next chase group on the road caught me right before the final few turns and final climb (a hill on a normal day, but a brutal punch after nearly 325km of racing). The original chase group I was in raced for 40th, and this second chase I finished in sprinted for 52nd. I was second in this sprint, finishing 53rd on the day.

Overall, I am happy to see that I have the strength and race acumen to be racing with the big dawgs, but I am quite a bit bummed to miss out on finishing with the group racing for 40th due to a relatively silly mechanical. Unbound is a beast, and I will definitely be back for a shot at redemption!

Follow me at
:http://youtube.com/justinmcquerryhttp
://instagram.com/j_mcquerry/http
://strava.com/athletes/justinmcquerryhttp
://facebook.com/justin.mcquerry/
